title: BioWare responds to players' lust over new companion Jaal - welcome to the age of horny marketing | GamesRadar+
text:
News Shares 
Did you think games like Overwatch had the market on "AAA video game characters people want to have sex with" cornered? Not even close. A recent reveal of Mass Effect: Andromeda companion Jaal has got fans' hearts all a-flutter , as they quietly (or on sites like Twitter and Tumblr, not so quietly) pine for this sexy twi'lek… cat… squid… thing. 
But really, this shouldn't be a surprise. Gamers have been fantasizing about fictional characters since Samus was little more than a collection of squares on our buzzing CRT televisions. What is surprising is how well BioWare seems to be embracing the idea. "I am gunna bang that monocle rat lobster." I'm sorry, Dad. This is what I do for a living. February 10, 2017 ANDROMEDA VOCAB:Angara (Singular)Angara (Plural)Angaran (Adjective)Jaal (Sexy Beast?)#space February 10, 2017 @bengelinas Have we released his voice yet? I don't think we have. My God, just wait... February 10, 2017 Highlight of my day was explaining to our marketing team all the ways banging can be achieved, and what a bangable bits are brandished February 9, 2017 
That last tweet is particularly telling - far from the days of Ken Levine asking people to stop drawing porn of Elizabeth because "I die a little inside with every pageview," BioWare is actively encouraging Jaal lust and looking at how they can turn it to its advantage. 
We've already seen how this tactic can backfire, courtesy of Gearbox head Randy Pitchford tweeting about a pornographic Battleborn sub-Reddit. His drawing attention to the subject was decried as being a weak "me too" attempt and the message board was subsequently flooded by Overwatch art. VERY NSFW, but I have received reports that BattlebornRule34 is now a thing on Reddit. LINK WITH CAUTION: https://t.co/laA7tR4Dgs January 16, 2017 
However BioWare chooses to proceed from here, one thing is clear: this is the age of appealing to a gamer's horniest sensibilities. Oh, and while we're here...
